words.meaning_en: an extended period or duration; 'long' here means extended in duration, not physical length
words.meaning_es: mucho tiempo, largo tiempo; 'long' aquÃ­ significa extendido en duraciÃ³n, no longitud fÃ­sica
words.origin_en: From Old English 'lang' meaning 'having great linear extent'. Extended metaphorically to time duration since Old English period.
words.origin_es: Del inglÃ©s antiguo 'lang' que significa 'tener gran extensiÃ³n lineal'. Extendido metafÃ³ricamente a la duraciÃ³n del tiempo desde el perÃ­odo del inglÃ©s antiguo.
examples: It's been a long time since we last met.

words.note: âš ï¸ IMPORTANT: 'Long' with TIME means DURATION (how much time), NOT distance. We use 'long' for time periods: 'a long time', 'how long?', 'for a long while'. We DON'T say 'a big time' or 'a large time'. Compare: 'a long road' (physical distance) vs 'a long time' (duration). Other time expressions with 'long': 'all day long', 'all night long', 'how long will it take?', 'as long as needed'.

words.meaning_en: making a deep, continuous sound; stomach making noise from hunger; early signs of discontent or unrest

words.meaning_en: to move toward the speaker or a specific place; to arrive; to happen or occur

words.note: âš ï¸ Key difference: Use 'COME' for movement TOWARD the speaker or destination. Example: 'Come to my office' (you move toward me). Contrast with 'GO' which means movement AWAY.

words.meaning_en: to move away from the speaker or to a different place; to leave; to function or work

words.note: âš ï¸ Key difference: Use 'GO' for movement AWAY from the speaker or toward another destination. Example: 'Go to his office' (you move away from me toward him). Contrast with 'COME' which means movement TOWARD.

words.meaning_en: a hard, aromatic seed from a tropical tree used as a spice in cooking and baking; in soccer, a move where you kick the ball between an opponent's legs

words.meaning_en: a medical device consisting of a tube and plunger used to inject fluids into or withdraw fluids from the body

words.meaning_en: to arrive or appear, especially when expected; to be visible or become noticeable; to embarrass someone by being better than them

words.meaning_en: to stay in a place longer than necessary; to remain or persist; to take a long time to leave or disappear
words.meaning_es: permanecer; quedarse en un lugar mÃ¡s tiempo del necesario; persistir; tardar mucho tiempo en irse o desaparecer
words.origin_en: From Middle English 'lengeren', meaning 'to dwell, tarry'. Related to Old English 'lengan' (to prolong).
words.origin_es: Del inglÃ©s medio 'lengeren', que significa 'permanecer, demorar'. Relacionado con el inglÃ©s antiguo 'lengan' (prolongar).
examples: Don't linger in the hallway.

She lingered at the door, hoping to talk to him.

words.meaning_en: a tool with a rubber cup on a stick used to clear blocked drains and toilets; the part of a syringe or pump that moves up and down
words.meaning_es: desatascador; herramienta con una ventosa de goma en un palo usada para desatascar desagÃ¼es e inodoros; el Ã©mbolo de una jeringa o bomba que se mueve arriba y abajo
words.origin_en: From 'plunge' (to thrust into water or downward) + '-er' (agent suffix). The verb 'plunge' comes from Old French 'plongier'.

examples: I need a plunger to unclog the toilet.

The plunger creates suction to remove blockages.

words.meaning_en: the highest point or top of something; in geometry, a point where two or more lines meet to form an angle; the top of the head; plural: vertices

words.meaning_en: custom-made or adapted to fit a particular person or purpose; specifically designed or modified to suit particular needs or requirements

words.meaning_en: the activity of making things skillfully by hand; creating or designing something with care and skill; in video games, making items from materials

words.meaning_en: the fact or condition of being responsible and answerable for one's actions, decisions, or policies; obligation to accept responsibility or to account for one's actions

examples: The company promotes accountability at all levels.

words.meaning_en: causing or likely to cause harm, damage, or injury; detrimental or injurious to health, well-being, or the environment
